subject: Sexual Health
title: Peer Pressure and Belonging
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on Peer Pressure and Belonging.

hook.text: During puberty, the need to belong to a peer group becomes almost as powerful as the need to eat.

buildup.text: The brain's reward system becomes hypersensitive to social acceptance and rejection during adolescence.

discovery.text: fMRI studies show teen brains light up more intensely than adult brains when receiving social approval.

twist.text: This wiring evolved to help teens separate from parents and form alliances, a survival advantage in our past.

climax.text: Understanding why peer pressure feels so powerful helps teens make conscious choices rather than automatic ones.

punchline.text: Belonging feels urgent because the teen brain says it is.

quiz.question: How do teen brains respond to social approval compared to adults?
